Is using the solidus ('/>') required when using the XHTML serialization of HTML5 (by sending the document with Content-Type: application/xhtml+xml)?
Matjas: only if you omit the end tag
Matjas: in xml you can do <foo></foo> or <foo/>, they mean the same
e.g. or

Hixie: So would be valid HTML5 (in XML mode)?
MikeSmith: well, obviously build.py isn't so nice, either
Matjas: well you need src="" and alt="" also, but yeah, from a syntax perspective it's correct in XML
Matjas: is valid XHTML5, yes
it's just like XHTML1 :-)

Why is it that html5.validator.nu chokes on </img>? http://html5.validator.nu/?doc=http://mathiasbynens.be/edu/test.html&showsource=yes Note that this is in HTML serialization mode.
HTML != XHTML
</img> is only valid in XHTML
(The reason why I made it modify the file in place is that I don't want to rewrite the identity of the class just to apply a workaround for release binaries
hsivonen: ah
yeah, that makes sense
Fair enough. Now, to trigger XML mode, I just need to serve the file with a header like Content-Type: application/xhtml+xml;charset=UTF-8, right?

you don't need the doctype in xhtml mode
but if you have it it has to be uppercase
<!DOCTYPE html>

Philip`, 1) Often I do know and trust the domain name.  2) Even if I'm not worried about a malicious URL, the name often gives a hint to the content.  3) Trolls are more likely to use a stock URL shortener for goatse than to register a whole domain.

Are spaces prohibited in href?  If so, why?  Do browsers not encode them consistently when making the request?
AryehGregor: They're prohibited in the URL syntax, I think
The validator says so.  Do you know why?
and it's not HTML's job to redefine the valid URL syntax
Well, it looks like the browser encodes the spaces as %20.  Something must tell it to do so, unless that's unspecced.
Anyway, it's HTML's job to say what markup is valid.  It could provide a preprocessing algorithm and then say the URL is valid HTML if the result of the preprocessing is a valid URL.
AryehGregor: It does
http://www.whatwg.org/specs/web-apps/current-work/multipage/urls.html#valid-url
The %20 thing comes from the "resolve an address" algorithm
Okay, so can anyone actually answer my original question rather than giving me procedural reasons for why the question doesn't make sense?
Which is, I think, part of the spec-hot-potato that is the URL specification
Is there some reason to ban spaces in href/src/etc.?
AryehGregor: From HTML's point of view it is because RFC3987 says so
I imagine the RFC says tht so they people can split lists of URLs on spaces to get distinct URLs
Why does HTML have to require that URLs in HTML match RFC3987?
for example
That's incompatible with URL processing in HTML already.
It doesn't
It requires RFCs match RFC3986 or if the document is encoded in UTF-8 or UTF-16 it matches RFC3987
(IIRC)
s/RFCs/URLs/ I assume?
Yeah
gsnedders: That is mising the point somewhat
Of course, it's me.
What do you expect?
AryehGregor: I assume because changing the definition of valid HTML would be a huge fight for no particular purpose
You don't really gain much by allowing literal spaces
doesn't think it was a very common validation error
Also you lose compatibility with tools that expect syntactically valid URL
s
I was asking because I noticed the error when validating a site (not one I control).
...when they're hooked into an HTML parser and a dumb attribute-value extractor
although actually you get the same problem even when not involving HTML, because some sites send spaces in URLs in HTTP redirect headers
so I guess those tools should just be fixed

hey folks, WebIDL question -- if an interface 'operation void foo(in long a);' is called as x.foo() from JS
should that throw an exception? since 'a' does not have [Optional], or will the argument be 'undefined' in JS, and then converted to a long (0?)?
Treating it as undefined doesn't apply because it's a host object
I think throw TypeError
hmm, ok
the WebIDL draft doesn't seem to mention this case at all
It does
http://dev.w3.org/2006/webapi/WebIDL/#call
It falls into step 3 of that
well, that depends on what happens in the overload resolution
there's even an ed note that says to test how implementations actually behave with too few or too many args :)
the question is I guess whether the type list is "undefined" in that case, or is the wrong length
I think it is
iirc (whithout reading any specs or anyhting) this ase is underdefined
I think the simplest reading is that it throws TypeError, but I don't really trust the spec to be right about that

the a11y community sure write bad alt text
Hixie: I find that too.  Which is very surprising.  Good alt text is ridiculously easy if you know wtf you're doing.
doesn't get why anyone ever has issues with it, but they do for some reason, so shrug.
Because normal people have no reason to learn how to write good alt text, because they have so few blind users that it makes no practical difference to them.
HTML cannot mandate solutions contrary to economics.

I've found that good alt text has been helpful for me personally.  I spent quite a while with a broken image once, frex, on a page that I read fairly regularly, because the alt-text was so good that I didn't notice it was broken.
supposes it's kind of weird that he considers it helpful that it hid the existence of a broken image.
I only found out about it when I made my 404 page start emailing me.
Just because there are isolated cases where it worked well doesn't mean that it would have been worth the effort to learn how, if you weren't involved in standards anyway.
(so that you need the knowledge for non-authoring purposes)
TabAtkins_, oh, right, I meant to ask you -- actually, I did ask you -- could you look at this, since you're a Chromium person and all?  http://code.google.com/p/chromium/issues/detail?id=45804

True, I acquired the knowledge because of involvement in standards, but my point is that it's *very easy* knowledge.  It takes less than 5 minutes to learn.  This makes it even worse that some of the a11y people can't do it right in their examples, at least.
It might take less than five minutes to learn how to do it, but people won't learn it anyway unless there's obvious and immediate benefit.
Most people don't formally learn HTML at all, they just imitate existing use and maybe read some tutorials or skim a book.
If it looks right to them, then it's good enough.
Yeah, I know that.  I'm specifically complaining about a11y people, though.
And their bad examples.
Probably people who do use alt don't bother to learn the correct way because they think they already know it.
Then it doesn't matter how easy it is to learn.
